???

Agricultural sustainable standards are an important non-state governance intervention to reduce commodities production and trading pressure on biodiversity 

In exchange for following a set of best practices on economic, social, and environmental criteria,  adopting farms receive a label certifying that they follow such standards (Lambin and Thorlakson, 2018). The label gives farmers access to a market share of consumers willing to pay a higher price for prime products (Ferraro et al., 2005)

Often, this translates to economic gains for farmers and positive social outcomes (Meemken et al., 2021; Oya et al., 2018). Despite this, conservation benefits derived from certification are less clear (Blackman and Rivera, 2011; Meemken et al., 2021).

Even though some evidence has been published (e.g. Haggar et al., 2015; Hardt et al., 2015), they are not conclusive and whether or not observed differences can be attributed to sustainable standards or some existing pre-condition remains an emerging research question (Meemken et al., 2021).

Tayleur et al., 2018. Where are commodity crops certified, and what does it mean for conservation and poverty alleviation? Biological Conservation


???

Globally, certified crop areas are rising, in particular in tropical biodiverse countries (Tayleur et al., 2017). Among the products certified, coffee is one of the main crops, with over 2 million ha and an estimated 20-40 % of the global production certified. This is mostly produced in Colombia (300 thousand ha), Brazil (200 thousand ha), and Peru (160 thousand ha) (https://standardsmap.org/en/trends).

## 

???

To shed light on agricultural certification impacts on conservation and, more specifically, about potential synergies between private sustainable standards and compliance to government environmental policies, we will address the following questions: (i) are there detectable effects of certification in reducing on-farm deforestation rates and (ii) in increasing vegetation levels? Considering that the vegetation cover requirements from the Native Vegetation Law can be set on-farm or off-farm in the case of Legal Reserves, (iii) the certification induces farms to have higher vegetation cover? And finally, (iv) are there differences caused by certification on APP vegetation cover? To answer those questions, we will apply a robust counterfactual approach with before-after-control impact evaluation, considering a group of over 500 certified properties from one of the largest coffee-producing areas in Brazil.
